document.docAuthor: Santos, Allan Paulo Moreira & Nessimian, Jorge Luiz
document.masterDocTitle: Description of a new species of Byrsopteryx (Trichoptera: Hydroptilidae) from Rio de Janeiro State, Brazil, including its immature stages

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Description of a new species of Byrsopteryx (Trichoptera: Hydroptilidae) from Rio de Janeiro State, Brazil, including its immature stages

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Byrsopteryx
Flint 1981
: 27
[ type species:
B . mirifica
Flint, 1981
, original designation];
Harris & Holzenthal 1994
[revision, placement];
Bowles et al . 1999
: 45
[placement].

subSubSection.paragraph:
Byrsopteryx carioca
sp
. nov . (
Figs. 1–21
)

Diagnosis. The male of
Byrsopteryx carioca
sp. nov.
resembles that of
B . abrelata
in many respects. Males of both species have an elongate sternum VIII, elongate dorsolateral processes on segment IX, each narrowing distally to an acute downturned apex, and the subgenital plate is wide basally and narrow apically in ventral view, with a mesal projection. Males of the new species can be distinguished from those of
B . abrelata
and other species in the genus by segment IX possessing a pair of ventral, stout, spine-like processes posteriorly, by the dorsolateral processes from segment IX each with a basal acute ventral projection when viewed laterally, and by the apex of the phallus bearing internally a short bifid sclerite.

Females of the new species can be distinguished from those of other
Byrsopteryx
species by segment VI lacking a ventromesal process, by segment VIII being almost as long as wide, and by the sclerotized, anteriorly rounded vaginal apparatus with a pair of lightly sclerotized lateral arms posteriorly.

Byrsopteryx
larvae were previously described for
B . mirifica
and
B . bipartiterga
Botosaneanu, 2000
. Larvae of
Byrsopteryx carioca
sp. nov.
are very similar to those of
B . mirifica (
Holzenthal & Harris 1992
)
. However, in
B . carioca
the abdominal segments of the larvae are not laterally compressed as in
B . mirifica
and the case is slightly depressed dorsoventrally. We cannot distinguish larvae of the new species from
B . bipartiterga
because few features were provided in the original larval description (
Botosaneanu 2000
).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–3.
Byrsopteryx carioca
sp. nov.
1: male head, dorsal view; 2: male right forewing, dorsal view; 3: male right hind wing, dorsal view. Scale bar = 0.2 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Va r ia ti o n . Length 2.4–2.6 mm (n= 3 ). Other features of the paratypes similar to the holotype .
Female . Length 3.0– 3.1 mm (n= 2 ). Coloration and features of head and thorax as in male. Abdominal segment VI without ventromesal process.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 4–7.
Byrsopteryx carioca
sp. nov.
, male genitalia. 4: ventral view; 5: dorsal view; 6: left lateral view; 7: phallus, dorsal view. Scale bar = 0.1 mm.

FIGURES 8–9.
Byrsopteryx carioca
sp. nov.
, female genitalia. 8: terminal segments of abdomen (in detail, plumose seta), ventral view; 9: vaginal apparatus, ventral view. Scale bar = 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Larval case . Length 2.3–3.7 mm (n= 14 ). Made entirely of silk with bits of mineral material incorporated, generally with filamentous algae attached on surface ( Figs. 18, 19 ); slightly depressed dorsoventrally, with poorly closed dorsal seam; anterior and posterior openings circular.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 10–15.
Byrsopteryx carioca
sp. nov.
, larva. 10: head, dorsal view; 11: head, ventral view; 12: thoracic nota, dorsal view; 13: right fore-, mid-, and hind legs, respectively, right lateral view; 14: abdominal tergites VIII and IX, dorsal view; 15: left anal proleg, left lateral view. Scale bar = 0.1 mm.

FIGURES 16–17.
Byrsopteryx carioca
sp. nov.
, pupa. 16: right mandible, ventral view; 17: abdominal hook plates, dorsal view. Scale bar = 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:

.
BRAZIL
, Rio de Janeiro State , Rio de Janeiro, Floresta da Tijuca: Parque Nacional da Tijuca, Rio Humaitá,
22 ° 57 ’ 30.1 ”S
43 ° 17 ’ 21.4 ”W
, 475 m ,
24 .x. 2009
, A.P.M. Santos leg . ( DZRJ ).

Paratypes
. Same data as holotype ,
2 males
,
2 females
( DZRJ / MZSP ).

Additional material examined. Same data as holotype ,
9 larvae
,
6 pupae
( DZRJ ); same data except,
14 .i. 2009
, A.P.M. Santos, L.L. Dumas, and R.S.G.G. Carrijo,

,

3 pupae
,
2 larvae
( MZSP ).

Etymology. The species name refers to the city of Rio de Janeiro, where the species was collected.
Carioca
is a gentile adjective for the inhabitants of this city. The word “ carioca ” comes from the Tupi language and means “white man’s house”.
Distribution. Rio de Janeiro State, Brazil .

Biology and habitat . Parque Nacional da Tijuca is located in a mountainous area in the center of Rio de Janeiro city, and includes reforested fragments of the Atlantic Forest. The specimens were collected from a second order portion of the Rio Humaitá within the conservation unit. In this portion, the stream was fastflowing and ran over bedrock, in an area exposed to light.

Larvae and pupae were found on rock surfaces, particularly in areas with little water; occasionally they were above the water line. Pupae occurred in small groups and pupal cases were attached to the substrate by the anterior stalks. Gut contents of larvae (n= 4 ) contained almost exclusively diatom frustules, as described for other species (
Holzenthal & Harris 1992
,
Harris & Holzenthal 1994
).

Adults of
B. carioca
sp. nov.
were collected only during the day and, as typical for the genus, ran actively on the rock surface. Some adults of the new species had the uncommon behavior of rotating the body around the axis of the head, after running rapidly and stopping quickly.
